annotation.infon: negative regulation of multicellular organism growth|GO:0040015
annotation.text: Here, we report that an mmBCFA-derived sphingolipid, d17iso-glucosylceramide, is a critical metabolite in regulating growth and development. Further analysis indicated that this lipid function is mediated by TORC1 and antagonized by the NPRL-2/3 complex in the intestine. Strikingly, the essential lipid function is bypassed by activating TORC1 or inhibiting NPRL-2/3.

Here, we report that an mmBCFA-derived sphingolipid, d17iso-glucosylceramide, is a critical metabolite in regulating growth and development. Further analysis indicated that this lipid function is mediated by TORC1 and antagonized by the NPRL-2/3 complex in the intestine. Strikingly, the essential lipid function is bypassed by activating TORC1 or inhibiting NPRL-2/3.

Here, we report that an mmBCFA-derived sphingolipid, d17iso-glucosylceramide, is a critical metabolite in regulating growth and development. Further analysis indicated that this lipid function is mediated by TORC1 and antagonized by the NPRL-2/3 complex in the intestine. Strikingly, the essential lipid function is bypassed by activating TORC1 or inhibiting NPRL-2/3.

In this study, we discovered that (1) an mmBCFA-derived glucosylceramide (d17iso-GlcCer) mediates the function of mmBCFAs in promoting postembryonic growth and development and (2) d17iso-GlcCer acts through a signaling system that includes the NPRL-2/NPRL-3 protein complex (negative factor) and TORC1 (positive factor) to promote postembryonic development.

annotation.text: Among four suppressors identified in this screen, and the tat-2 mutations from a previous elo-5(-) suppressor screen (Seamen et al., 2009), ku540 was the only mutation that rescued elo-5(-) larvae to adults and permitted growth for more than one generation without mmBCFA supplementation or restoration of mmBCFA synthesis (Figure 2B-E; see 'Materials and methods').

annotation.text: We fused a 22-amino acid fragment of the C-terminal end of rap-1 to the C-terminal end of daf-15 and named it daf-15::rap-1(22). We found that 56.0% of elo-5(-) mutants carrying daf-15::rap-1(22) bypassed L1 arrest and reached L3 to adult stage (n = 161; normalized against elo-5(-/+) heterozygotes containing the transgene; Figure 4A,B).

annotation.text: These results led to the conclusion that TORC1 acts downstream of d17iso-GlcCer to promote L1 growth and development and that this activity is negatively regulated by NPRL-2/3.

annotation.text: The fact that elo-5(-);nprl-3(ku540) animals treated with ife-2 RNAi, that targets intestinal but not neuronal expression of the gene (Syntichaki et al., 2007), are L1 arrested (Table 1) also points to the requirement of TORC1 activity in the intestine.

annotation.text: The fact that elo-5(-);nprl-3(ku540) animals treated with ife-2 RNAi, that targets intestinal but not neuronal expression of the gene (Syntichaki et al., 2007), are L1 arrested (Table 1) also points to the requirement of TORC1 activity in the intestine.

annotation.infon: positive regulation of nematode larval development|GO:0061063
annotation.text: To directly evaluate a role of intestinal TORC1 in mmBCFA/d17iso-GlcCer regulated growth, we made a raga-1Q63L TORC1 hyperactivating transgene driven by the intestinal-specific promoter ges-1 (Edgar and McGhee, 1986). We found that elo-5(-) animals containing this transgene bypassed the L1 arrest (37.9%, n = 132, normalized against elo-5(-/+) heterozygotes containing the transgene; Figure 4A). The rescue with the intestinal expression was similar to that by a ubiquitously expressed raga-1Q63L transgene (above).

annotation.infon: positive regulation of TOR signaling cascade|GO:0032008
annotation.text: Because the biochemical assay for p70S6K phosphorylation has not been established in C. elegans' TOR-related studies, we adopted the strategy by Sheaffer et al. (2008), where localization of FIB-1, a Box C/D small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein (snoRNP) was used as a marker of TORC1 activation in C. elegans. We found that the nucleolar localized FIB-1 was dramatically reduced in intestinal cells of mmBCFA-deficient [elo-5(RNAi)] animals (Figure 4C).

annotation.infon: negative regulation of TOR signaling cascade|GO:0032007
annotation.text: Because the biochemical assay for p70S6K phosphorylation has not been established in C. elegans' TOR-related studies, we adopted the strategy by Sheaffer et al. (2008), where localization of FIB-1, a Box C/D small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein (snoRNP) was used as a marker of TORC1 activation in C. elegans. We found that the nucleolar localized FIB-1 was dramatically reduced in intestinal cells of mmBCFA-deficient [elo-5(RNAi)] animals (Figure 4C). Furthermore, nprl-3(-) rescued the FIB-1 expression and nucleolar localization in elo-5(-) back to that of wild type (Figure 4C).

We found that the nucleolar localized FIB-1 was dramatically reduced in intestinal cells of mmBCFA-deficient [elo-5(RNAi)] animals (Figure 4C). Furthermore, nprl-3(-) rescued the FIB-1 expression and nucleolar localization in elo-5(-) back to that of wild type (Figure 4C).

annotation.infon: positive regulation of TOR signaling cascade|GO:0032008
annotation.text: In wild-type animals, FIB-1 is highly expressed and localized in the nucleolus, where it methylates pre-rRNAs during ribosome maturation, but the expression is decreased and no longer localized to the nucleolus in let-363/TOR(-) animals (Sheaffer et al., 2008).

annotation.infon: negative regulation of TOR signaling cascade|GO:0032007
annotation.text: In wild-type animals, FIB-1 is highly expressed and localized in the nucleolus, where it methylates pre-rRNAs during ribosome maturation, but the expression is decreased and no longer localized to the nucleolus in let-363/TOR(-) animals (Sheaffer et al., 2008).

In wild-type animals, FIB-1 is highly expressed and localized in the nucleolus, where it methylates pre-rRNAs during ribosome maturation, but the expression is decreased and no longer localized to the nucleolus in let-363/TOR(-) animals (Sheaffer et al., 2008).
